questions.q: In web terms, what is a 'Client'?
options: The computer that stores the website
questions.explanation: The client is the device or software that requests to see a website.

options: On a remote computer called a server
questions.explanation: Server-side code (like PHP or Node.js) runs on the server before sending the result to you.

questions.q: What does HTML provide to a webpage?
questions.explanation: HTML is the skeleton of the page; it defines headings, paragraphs, and links.

questions.q: Which protocol is used to transfer web pages over the internet?
questions.explanation: HTTP (HyperText Transfer Protocol) is the standard for web communication.

questions.q: What is a 'Database' in the context of a web server?
options: A place to store user data like names and passwords
The plastic case of the server
questions.explanation: Servers use databases to remember information for later use.

questions.q: True or False: A server is basically a computer that is always on and connected to the internet.
questions.explanation: Servers are built to run 24/7 to provide services to clients.

questions.q: True or False: Back-end development refers to the parts of a website the user sees.
questions.explanation: Back-end is the 'behind the scenes' logic; Front-end is what the user sees.

questions.q: True or False: JavaScript can be used on both the Client and the Server.
questions.explanation: With tools like Node.js, JavaScript is now a powerful full-stack language.

questions.q: True or False: An IP address is like a home address for a computer on the network.
questions.explanation: The IP address tells the internet where to send requested data.

questions.q: True or False: CSS is used to make a website look beautiful with colors and fonts.
questions.explanation: Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) handle the presentation and layout.

questions.q: What happens when you type 'google.com' into your browser?
options: The browser (client) sends a request to a Google server, which processes it and sends back the files needed to show the page.

questions.q: Why do we use 'Servers' instead of just keeping all data on our own computers?
options: Servers allow many different people to access the same information at the same time from anywhere in the world.
